subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 and public classes

messageBody:
Ilja Preuss wrote:

> Do you otherwise manage to have a one-to-one relationship between public and
> published? I would be interested to know how you do *that*...

Not perfect, but close. The other flaky part is sample code. I don't
make any promises about that, but quite a bit of it is public in a
separate package. In XOM at least outside of samples and tests
everything that's public (or protected) is published. This requires
careful thought and design, and you need to think twice (and then think
again) before making anything public. If you're wrong and something
needs to be public, you can always make it public later; but it's much
harder to take a public method away.

The most common mistake that prevents unifying public and published is
excessive package differentiation. Too often code is separated into more
packages than it needs to be. As I said earlier, this should be less of
a problem in future JDKs once package access can be extended into
subpackages.
